comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: Milton C. Elliott (1879-1928) was a lawyer from Virginia, based in Washington DC, son of Warren G. Elliott (1848-1906), president of the Atlantic Coast Line.  In May 1914, Milton C. Elliott delivered an address to the American Bankers' Association, titled "The Directors of the Federal Reserve Banks."

comment.author: 15283643@N04
comment._content: This is what people in their mid-30s looked like around 1913. He could pass for 60 today.

comment.author: 11418107@N02
comment._content: I was thinking that too, technogeo, and noticing that he died at 49.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Milton Elliott, obviously a man of substance, was the counsel to the Federal Reserve Board, which had been set up as part of the new Federal Reserve banking system. As a result of this connection, he carried considerable weight in banking circles: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E0DE1DF103FE2...

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
A related Bain/LOC photo, also from January, 1914, shows the two members of the Federal Reserve Board's bank-locating committee, William Gibbs McAdoo, and David Franklin Houston, opening hearings in New York City:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/4733200424/in/photostream/]

comment.author: 54904823@N00
comment._content: I started an entry for him in Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Courtright_Elliott
